page.title: 02FEATURES OF BUCKHURST HILL
page.content: Buckhurst Hill extends westwards from the River Roding for about two miles. It merges into Woodford going south and Loughton to the north. When Buckhurst Hill first developed it had no place of worship so locals had to cross the Rodoing by the often flooded church path to Chigwell church on the other side of the valley.In 1837,however, this situation was rectified by the building ,along the High Road , of St. John the Baptist.Also on the High Road is the Bald-Faced Stag,a pub standing on the site of a coaching inn that served travellers on the London to Newmarket coach road(now the A11). Buckhurst Hill is now a suburb of London,with a mixture of grand,old houses and new housing.The housing is broken up by parts of Epping Forest, known as Lords Bushes.
